_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Testing of Loading and Storage Emergency Shutdown Equipment
_prev_prog_3.Description:
The Woodward plant has a comprehensive Safety-Loss Prevention/Process Safety Management (PSM) Program and is subject to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's standard for process management of highly hazardous chemicals found in 29 CFR Part 1910.119.



Key elements of the PSM program include:  1) stringent design of equipment which incorporates substantial safety factors and include state of the art monitoring and control instrumentation; 2) extensive process safety information that is accurate and up to date; 3) well trained operating, maintenance and contract personnel; 4) written safety, operating, and maintenance procedures; 5) mechanical integrity procedures for process equipment inspections and quality control; 6) management of change and pre-startup review procedures; 7) periodic, detailed evaluation of each process area by a team utilizing HAZOP methodology; 8) regular PSM program audits; and 9) employee participation in every element of the PSM program.



The Woodward Plant process is nitrogen product manufacturing facility which consists of seven interconnected and co-located production/storage units.  These units have similar prevention program elements and are listed together in Section 7.  The units and their updated PHA dates are as follows:  



Ammonia Plant- Revalidation April 2011

Urea Ammonium Nitrate Plant #1 - Revalidation March 2013

Urea Ammonium Nitrate Plant #2 - Revalidation May 2014

Nitric Acid Plant #1 - Revalidation March 2013

Nitric Acid Plant #2 - Revalidation June 2014 

Offsights/Utilities Systems - Revalidation August 2012  

Ammonia Storage and Loading - Revalidation January 2015

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The CF Woodward Plant (Woodward, Oklahoma) manufactures anhydrous ammonia, urea solutions, urea ammonium nitrate solution and by-product gaseous carbon dioxide.  Intermediates in the manufacture of the products include nitric acid, and ammonium nitrate solution.  The regulated substance, as defined by 40 CFR Part 68, which is present at the facility in more than a threshold quantity is ammonia.



It is CF's policy to prevent accidental releases from the Woodward Plant by effective process safety management programs and procedures that include:  participation by all plant employees in every element of PSM; regular analysis of process hazards utilizing current and accurate process safety information; maintaining current and accurate written operating procedures; providing timely and comprehensive training for all employees involved in operating and maintaining process equipment; overseeing the activities of contractors and ensuring that they are trained to perform their job safely; following established pre-startup safety review and management of change procedures to ensure that modifications are adequately evaluated for safety; administering a comprehensive mechanical integrity program to ensure that process equipment is maintained in accordance with good engineering practices and accepted industry standards; investigation of incidents when they occur to promptly correct deficiencies and learn from the experience, and audit the entire PSM program on a regular basis to verify that all elements, procedures, and systems are in place and adequate.  In addition, it is the Woodward Plants policy to maintain a current and accurate written emergency response plan, a system to notify facility neighbors in the event of a release, and to coordinate emergency response planning with local authorities and exercise those plans annually.



Offsite Consequence Analysis:

The Woodward Plant's Toxic Worst Case Scenario involves anhydrous ammonia and has offsite impact.  The Alternati

ve Release Scenario for ammonia is a 2" pipe break, resulting in the release of 80,000 pounds over a 60-minute period.  The distance to the toxic endpoint for ammonia (200 ppm) is estimated to be 0.57 miles.  The Alternative Release Scenario for ammonia (water solution, greater than 20% ammonia) is seal failure on the Strong Aqua Ammonia Pump resulting in a release of 1592 pounds over a 10 minute period.  The distance to the toxic endpoint in 0.1 miles.  The Flammable Worst Case Release Scenario for Syngas (Hydrogen and Methane) is for the release of 8680 pounds of Hydrogen and Methane with an overpressure endpoint of 1 pound per square inch at 0.2 miles.  The Alternative Release Scenario for Syngas (Hydrogen) involves a 1" tube failure at E-2222 with a release of 1110 pounds over a 10 minute period.  The overpressure endpoint of 1 pound per square inch would be at 0.08 miles.



Accidental Release Prevention Program:

The Woodward Plant has a comprehensive Process Safety Management (PSM) Program and is subject to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's standard for process safety management of highly hazardous chemicals found in 29 CFR Part 1910.119.  Key elements of the PSM program include:  1) stringent design standards of equipment which incorporate substantial safety factors and include state of the art monitoring and control instrumentation designed specific for ammonia manufacturing and storage service; 2) extensive ammonia manufacturing process specific process safety information that is accurate and up to date; 3) well trained operating, maintenance, and contract personnel; 4) written operating and maintenance procedures and safe work practices specific to the ammonia manufacturing industry; 5) mechanical integrity procedures for process equipment inspections and quality control; 6) management of change and pre-startup safety review procedures; 7) periodic, detailed evaluations of each process area by a team utilizing HAZOP methodology; 8) regul

ar PSM program audits; and 9) employee participation in every element of the PSM program.



Five-Year Accident History:  

A release of 613 pounds of ammonia to the atmosphere occurred at the Woodward Facility on November 16, 2011 at 4:30 am.  The release was a result of an overpressure situation in the process (UAN #2 Plant) that casued a pressure relief valve to vent ammonia to the atmosphere.  The release resulted in off-site impact.  A neighbor approximately 1 mile from the plant was forced to shelter in place due to the strong odor of ammonia at his business location.



On October 15, 2012 a maintenance technician in our maintenance shop had a solution of approximately 40% ammonia sprayed in his eyes when he opened a ball valve on a pump that had been in prior ammonia solution service.  The ammonia solution that was in the pump had pressured up and was released when he opened the valve.  The technician rinsed his eyes for 15 minutes and was then taken to the eye doctor for an evaluation.  He was prescribed an antibiotic as a precaution to prevent infection.  



On December 9, 2013 a maintenance technician was exposed to ammonia vapors while changing a filter from an in-line filter housing device.  The ammonia vapors caused a buring sensation to the employee's throat, lungs, and eyes.  The employee was taken to a doctor for a medical evaluation and was given a prescription inhaler as a precautionary measure.



On December 26, 2013 an operations technician was exposed to a solution of ammonia when he was opening a valve and the solution leaked and sprayed from the valve stem packing.  The solution sprayed the employee in the right eye.  After rinsing the eye at the nearest eyewash station the employee was taken to the doctor for a medical evaluation and was given a prescription eye drop as a precaution to prevent infection.  



Emergency Response Program:

The Woodward Facility has a comprehensive Emergency Response Program which includes a written plan that

is coordinated with local authorities, a 60-plus member emergency response team, and emergency notification system that utilizes both in-plant sirens and the Community Alert Network telephone system.  Woodward Plant personnel are active members of the Woodward County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).  The plant exercises its emergency response plan annually and also participates in countywide drills that are staged by the LEPC and other local emergency response authorities.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety:

The Woodward Facility has a comprehensive Safety program that includes written safety procedures, implemented safety programs, and safety training for all employees.  Thru utilization of the procedures, programs, and training, the Facility is continually assessing safety and opportunities for improvement.  Thru incident investigations and subsequent implementation/corrective measures associated with recommendations from the investigations, the Woodward Facility is involved in a continuous improvement in regards to safety.  In addition, the Facility annually takes part in a self-evaluation as part of the Voluntary Protection Program (VPP) to evaluate our Facility/Programs in regards to safety.
